title: Red Flags in Gym Contracts
content:
ğŸš© **Long-term commitment** (12-24 months) with high cancellation fees

ğŸš© **Automatic renewal** clauses that extend the contract without your explicit consent

ğŸš© **Price increase clauses** allowing the gym to raise fees at any time

ğŸš© **Liability waivers** attempting to absolve the gym of all responsibility for injuries

ğŸš© **Difficult cancellation procedures** (e.g., requiring certified mail or in-person visits)

ğŸš© **Maintenance fees** charged annually on top of monthly dues

title: Key Terms to Know
content:
ğŸ“ **Cooling-off Period**: A short window (usually 5 days under the CPA) after signing where you can cancel without penalty.

ğŸ“ **Initiation Fee**: A one-time fee charged when joining.

ğŸ“ **Pro-rata**: Partial payment for the portion of the month you used before the billing cycle starts.

ğŸ“ **Debit Order Authority**: Permission for the gym to automatically withdraw funds from your account.

title: Your Consumer Rights
content:
âš–ï¸ **Right to Cancel**: Under the Consumer Protection Act (CPA), you can cancel a fixed-term contract by giving 20 business days' notice. The gym may charge a reasonable cancellation penalty, but they cannot demand the full outstanding balance.

âš–ï¸ **Right to Fair Terms**: Terms that are excessively one-sided or unfair may be unenforceable.

âš–ï¸ **Right to Disclosure**: The total cost of credit and all fees must be clearly disclosed upfront.

title: Negotiation Tips
content:
ğŸ’¡ **Ask for a month-to-month option**: It might cost slightly more but gives you freedom to leave.

ğŸ’¡ **Waive the joining fee**: Sales consultants often have the discretion to waive this to close a deal.

ğŸ’¡ **Check for corporate discounts**: Your employer or medical aid (e.g., Discovery Vitality) might offer significant subsidies.

ğŸ’¡ **Request a trial**: Ask for a 1-week free trial before signing anything to test the facilities.

title: Red Flags in Medical Insurance
content:
ğŸš© **General Waiting Periods**: A 3-month period where no claims are paid, even for emergencies in some low-cost plans

ğŸš© **Condition-Specific Waiting Periods**: 12-month exclusions for pre-existing conditions

ğŸš© **Late Joiner Penalties**: Permanent extra fees added to your premium if you join a medical aid later in life

ğŸš© **Network Restrictions**: Being forced to use specific hospitals or doctors to avoid co-payments

ğŸš© **Co-payments**: Upfront fees you must pay for certain procedures (e.g., MRI scans, surgery)

ğŸš© **PMB Exclusions**: Plans that try to limit Prescribed Minimum Benefits (which is illegal for Medical Schemes but common in Medical Insurance products)

title: Key Terms to Know
content:
ğŸ“ **PMB (Prescribed Minimum Benefits)**: A list of chronic conditions and emergencies that all Medical Schemes MUST cover by law, regardless of your plan type.

ğŸ“ **Medical Scheme vs. Health Insurance**: Medical Schemes are non-profit and regulated to cover PMBs. Health Insurance is a risk product that pays out fixed amounts and may not cover comprehensive care.

ğŸ“ **Gap Cover**: A separate policy that pays the difference between what the doctor charges and what your medical aid pays.

ğŸ“ **Day-to-Day Benefits**: Funds allocated for GP visits and medicine, often limited.

title: Your Consumer Rights
content:
âš–ï¸ **Open Enrollment**: Medical Schemes cannot refuse you membership based on your health status (though they can impose waiting periods).

âš–ï¸ **Emergency Treatment**: You cannot be refused emergency medical treatment.

âš–ï¸ **PMB Coverage**: Schemes must pay for PMB conditions in full if you use a Designated Service Provider (DSP).

title: Negotiation Tips
content:
ğŸ’¡ **Choose a Network Plan**: You can save 15-20% on premiums by agreeing to use specific hospitals.

ğŸ’¡ **Review Annually**: Downgrade your plan if you are healthy and upgrade only when you plan a family or anticipate surgery.

ğŸ’¡ **Use State Facilities**: For PMBs, if your scheme's designated provider is unavailable, they must pay for an alternative provider.

title: Red Flags in Car Insurance
content:
ğŸš© **Commercial Use Exclusions**: Not being covered if you use your car for work (e.g., sales calls, delivery) without declaring it

ğŸš© **Unnamed Driver Exclusions**: No cover if anyone other than the nominated driver is behind the wheel

ğŸš© **Vague 'Reasonable Precautions' Clause**: Insurer refusing to pay because you left keys in the ignition or didn't lock the gate

ğŸš© **Betterment Clauses**: Being asked to contribute to repairs if new parts increase the car's value

ï¿½ï¿½ **Tracking Device Requirement**: Cover suspended if your tracker isn't working or tested regularly

title: Key Terms to Know
content:
ğŸ“ **Excess (First Amount Payable)**: The amount you must pay towards a claim before the insurer pays the rest.

ğŸ“ **Retail Value**: The average price a dealer would sell your car for (usually higher than Market or Trade value).

ğŸ“ **Comprehensive Cover**: Covers theft, fire, and accident damage to your car AND third parties.

ğŸ“ **Third Party Only**: Only covers damage you cause to other people's property.

title: Your Consumer Rights
content:
âš–ï¸ **Right to Reasons**: If a claim is rejected, the insurer must provide written reasons.

âš–ï¸ **Ombudsman**: You have the right to escalate unresolved disputes to the Ombudsman for Short-Term Insurance (OSTI).

âš–ï¸ **Fair Value**: You should be paid out the reasonable market value of the vehicle at the time of loss.

title: Negotiation Tips
content:
ğŸ’¡ **Adjust Your Excess**: Increasing your voluntary excess can significantly lower your monthly premium.

ğŸ’¡ **Update Your Details**: Secure parking, less mileage, or getting married can lower your risk profile and premium.

ğŸ’¡ **Combine Policies**: Insuring your car and home contents with the same provider often qualifies for a discount.

title: Red Flags in Rental Agreements
content:
ğŸš© **Illegal Deposit Deductions**: Clauses allowing the landlord to keep the deposit for 'fair wear and tear'

ğŸš© **Unannounced Inspections**: Landlord reserving the right to enter without reasonable notice

ğŸš© **Maintenance Shifts**: Making the tenant responsible for structural repairs (e.g., geyser, roof)

ğŸš© **Penalty Clauses**: Excessive penalties for late payment (e.g., 10% per day)

ğŸš© **Automatic Renewal**: Lease renewing for another full year if you forget to give notice

title: Key Terms to Know
content:
ğŸ“ **Deposit**: Security money held by the landlord. It MUST be invested in an interest-bearing account for the tenant's benefit.

ğŸ“ **Fair Wear and Tear**: Normal deterioration from living in the property (e.g., faded paint) which you are NOT liable for.

ğŸ“ **Incoming Inspection**: A mandatory check of the property's condition before you move in. If not done, the landlord cannot claim for damages later.

ğŸ“ **Breach**: Breaking a term of the contract (e.g., not paying rent).

title: Your Consumer Rights
content:
âš–ï¸ **Rental Housing Tribunal**: A free body that resolves disputes between landlords and tenants.

âš–ï¸ **Privacy**: You have the right to privacy; landlords cannot enter without notice or permission (except in emergencies).

âš–ï¸ **Deposit Return**: The deposit (plus interest) must be returned within 7 days of the lease ending (or 14-21 days if repairs are needed).

title: Negotiation Tips
content:
ğŸ’¡ **Cap the Increase**: Negotiate a fixed percentage for the annual rent increase (e.g., CPI + 1%) to avoid shocks.

ğŸ’¡ **Break Clause**: Ask for a clause allowing you to terminate early with 2 months' notice if your job moves.

ğŸ’¡ **Improvements**: If you improve the property (e.g., install security gates), ask for a rent reduction.

title: Red Flags in Employment Contracts
content:
ğŸš© **Broad Restraint of Trade**: Preventing you from working in the entire industry for years after leaving

ğŸš© **Unpaid Overtime**: 'All-inclusive' salary packages that violate the Basic Conditions of Employment Act (BCEA) for lower earners

ğŸš© **Deductions**: Clauses allowing the employer to deduct money for 'damages' without a disciplinary hearing

ğŸš© **Probation**: Indefinite or excessively long probation periods

ğŸš© **Intellectual Property**: Claiming ownership of *everything* you create, even in your own time

title: Key Terms to Know
content:
ğŸ“ **CTC (Cost to Company)**: The total package value, including benefits. Your cash salary will be lower.

ğŸ“ **Notice Period**: The time you must work after resigning. Usually 2-4 weeks.

ğŸ“ **Moonlighting**: Working a second job. Usually requires employer permission.

ğŸ“ **CCMA**: Commission for Conciliation, Mediation and Arbitration - the body that handles unfair dismissal.

title: Your Consumer Rights
content:
âš–ï¸ **Fair Dismissal**: You can only be fired for misconduct, incapacity, or operational requirements (retrenchment), and a fair process must be followed.

âš–ï¸ **Leave**: You are entitled to 21 consecutive days of annual leave per year.

âš–ï¸ **Sick Leave**: You get 30 days of paid sick leave in every 3-year cycle.

title: Negotiation Tips
content:
ğŸ’¡ **Review Dates**: Ask for a guaranteed salary review after 6 months if they can't meet your asking price now.

ğŸ’¡ **Flexibility**: Negotiate work-from-home days or flexible hours as part of your package.

ğŸ’¡ **Sign-on Bonus**: Ask for a one-off payment to cover the risk of moving jobs or lost bonuses.

title: Red Flags in Mortgage Agreements
content:
ğŸš© **Variable Interest Rate Exposure**: Not understanding how much your repayment will increase if the Prime rate goes up

ğŸš© **Balloon Payments**: A large lump sum due at the end of the loan term

ğŸš© **Early Termination Fees**: Penalties for paying off your bond sooner than the 20-year term

ğŸš© **Hidden Admin Fees**: Monthly service fees that add up over 20 years

ğŸš© **Mandatory Insurance**: Being forced to use the bank's expensive homeowner's insurance

title: Key Terms to Know
content:
ğŸ“ **Prime Rate**: The benchmark interest rate used by banks. You will get Prime plus or minus a percentage.

ğŸ“ **Bond Registration Costs**: Fees paid to attorneys to register the bond at the Deeds Office.

ğŸ“ **Initiation Fee**: A once-off fee charged by the bank to open the loan.

ğŸ“ **LTV (Loan to Value)**: The size of the loan compared to the property value. 100% LTV means no deposit.

title: Your Consumer Rights
content:
âš–ï¸ **Shop Around**: You are not obliged to accept the first offer. Use a bond originator to get quotes from all banks.

âš–ï¸ **Insurance Choice**: You have the right to use your own insurance provider for the building and life cover, provided it meets the bank's requirements.

âš–ï¸ **Disclosure**: The bank must provide a pre-agreement statement showing the full cost of credit.

title: Negotiation Tips
content:
ğŸ’¡ **Rate Concessions**: Even a 0.25% reduction in interest rate saves you thousands over 20 years.

ğŸ’¡ **Discount on Fees**: Ask for a discount on the initiation fee (often R6,000+).

ğŸ’¡ **Deposit**: Putting down even a small deposit (5-10%) usually secures a much better interest rate.

title: Red Flags in Phone/Internet Contracts
content:
ğŸš© **Fair Usage Policy (FUP)**: 'Uncapped' data that throttles your speed to a crawl after you use a certain amount

ğŸš© **Device Fees**: Continuing to pay for the phone handset even after the 24-month contract has ended

ğŸš© **Cancellation Penalties**: Being charged the full remaining subscription value if you cancel early

ğŸš© **Network Coverage**: Signing a 24-month contract without testing if you actually get signal at your home

ğŸš© **Content Services**: Automatically subscribing you to expensive daily content (games, news) via WASPs

title: Key Terms to Know
content:
ğŸ“ **Throttling**: Deliberately slowing down your internet speed.

ğŸ“ **SIM-only**: A contract for airtime/data only, without a device. Much cheaper and often month-to-month.

ğŸ“ **RICA**: The law requiring you to provide proof of address and ID to register a SIM card.

ğŸ“ **Top-up**: A contract type where you can't go over your limit unless you manually add airtime.

title: Your Consumer Rights
content:
âš–ï¸ **Data Rollover**: Under ICASA regulations, your data should roll over to the next month and not expire immediately.

âš–ï¸ **Cancellation**: You can cancel a fixed-term contract with 20 business days' notice (CPA), subject to a reasonable penalty.

âš–ï¸ **Number Portability**: You have the right to keep your phone number when switching networks.

title: Negotiation Tips
content:
ğŸ’¡ **Keep Your Phone**: If your phone is still good, switch to a SIM-only or prepaid plan to save 50%+.

ğŸ’¡ **Threaten to Leave**: Retention departments often have special 'loyalty' deals not advertised to the public.

ğŸ’¡ **Bundle**: Combining fibre and mobile data with one ISP can lead to discounts.
